Dispute_Type: Permanent residency application based on humanitarian and medical grounds
Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD's decision on medical inadmissibility and humanitarian considerations was reasonable
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 38(1)(c)
Evidence_Assessment: Medical evidence regarding heart conditions and potential for hospitalization
Decision_Outcome: IAD decision upheld; permanent residency denied
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate that health condition would not cause excessive demand
Legal_Rule: A foreign national is inadmissible if their health condition may reasonably cause excessive demand on health or social services
Procedural_Issue: Assessment of IAD’s adherence to procedural fairness and statutory requirements
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: IAD properly considered all relevant factors including humanitarian grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical reports on heart conditions, risk of hospitalization, stability of condition
Legal_Framework: IRPA and associated regulations governing inadmissibility and appeals
Applicant_Challenge: Challenging IAD's finding of medical inadmissibility
Defendant_Response: Government defended IAD's interpretation and application of IRPA
Remedy_Requested: Overturning of IAD decision and grant of permanent residency
Outcome: Denial of permanent residency; suggestion of visitor visas as alternative
Remedy_Sought: Permanent resident status based on family reunification and humanitarian grounds
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative appeal followed by judicial review
Claimant_Status: Foreign nationals applying for permanent residency as parents of a Canadian citizen
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Excessive demand on health services due to medical condition
Applicable_Process: Humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) assessment under IRPA
Outcome_of_Review: IAD decision found reasonable; no error in law or fact
Governing_Rule: IRPA s. 38(1)(c) – Medical inadmissibility based on excessive demand
